wikipedia_page.main: Ian Strang, A.R.E., R.E., (11 April 1886– 23 March 1952) was a British draughtsman and etcher who specialised in topographical subjects.

response: His sons Ian Strang (1886–1952) and David Strang (1887–1967) were both artists. William had at least one granddaughter, Joan Strang, born of David's short-lived marriage to the English soprano Dora Labbette.

The final generation of the revival are too numerous to name here but they might include such names as William Walcot, Frederick Griggs, Malcolm Osborne, James McBey, Ian Strang (son of William), and Edmund Blampied in Britain, John Sloan, Martin Lewis, Joseph Pennell and John Taylor Arms in the United States.  Griggs' pupil Joseph Webb only began etching in the last years before the collapse of the price bubble, and persisted in etching "Romantic pastoral landscapes" into the late 1940s.Meyrick, Robert, Joseph Webb: the lights that flit across my brain, pp. 25-30, 2007, Aberystwyth University: School of Art Museum and Gallery, PDF

In 1910, Euphemia met James Dickson Innes (1887–1914) at a cafe on the Boulevard du Montparnasse,Holroyd, 1997, p. 352. and the two began an affair which was more intense for Innes than for Euphemia who never restricted her relationships to just one man. According to Euphemia, they travelled through southern France together. Innes was already suffering from the tuberculosis that eventually killed him. In 1910 or 1911, with Augustus John, he established a small artistic commune at Nant Ddu cottage in north Wales. Visitors included John and Dorelia, Derwent Lees, Ian Strang, and Euphemia, who Innes painted against the background of Arenig Fawr. It was said that when the relationship was over, Innes buried a silver casket of love letters from Euphemia on the summit of Arenig, the mountain in some way representing the scale of Innes' unrequited love for her."Camden Town Group" Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Retrieved 1 November 2014.Holroyd, 1997, p. 354.

In 1891, William Strang portrayed his friend Clark in an etching entitled "The Philosopher",Jackson Maclehose, William Strang: Catalogue of His Etched Work, 1882–1912, Vol. 1 (1912), p. 79: "186. Portrait of J. B. Clark, 1891"; Ian Strang, "Some notes on William Strang", in The Print-collector's Quarterly, Vol. 24 (Frederick Keppel & Company, 1937), p. 403 as noted in the 1911 Encyclopædia Britannica. In 1894, a new translation of Lucian of Samosata's True History, with illustrations by Aubrey Beardsley,  William Strang, and J. B. Clark, was privately printed in an edition of 251 copies."Beardsley (Aubrey Vincent)" in T. Bose, Paul Tiessen, eds., Bookman's Catalogue Vol. 1 A-L: The Norman Colbeck Collection (UBC Press, 1987), p. 41 In 1895, Clark worked with Strang again to illustrate The Surprising Adventures of Baron MunchausenDavid Blamires, Telling Tales: The Impact of Germany on English Children's Books (Open Book Publishers, 2009), p. 424 and Sindbad the Sailor and Alibaba and the Forty Thieves,Sindbad the Sailor and Alibaba and the Forty Thieves, ill. William Strang and J. B. Clark (New York: Charles Scribner's Sons, 1895); Sindbad the Sailor and Alibaba and the Forty Thieves, ill. William Strang and J. B. Clark (London: Lawrence and Bullen, 1896) an edition which has been called reminiscent of the structure of Chinese boxes.Kristina Krüger, Studien zu Edmund Dulac (Tectum Wissenschaftsverlag, 2014), p. 63 (in German)
